children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: When prayer-meeting was over this man came up to Janet and said,
children.prevalue: When prayer meeting was over this man came up to Janet and said

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: May I see you home, Janet?
children.prevalue: May I see you home Janet

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Janet took his arm--as primly and shyly as if she were no more than sixteen, having her first escort home, Anne told the girls at Patty's Place later on.
children.prevalue: Janet took his arm as primly and shyly as if she were no more than sixteen having her first escort home Anne told the girls at Patty s Place later on

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Miss Shirley, permit me to introduce Mr. Douglas, she said stiffly.
children.prevalue: Miss Shirley permit me to introduce Mr Douglas she said stiffly

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mr. Douglas nodded and said, I was looking at you in prayer-meeting, miss, and thinking what a nice little girl you were.
children.prevalue: Mr Douglas nodded and said I was looking at you in prayer meeting miss and thinking what a nice little girl you were

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Such a speech from ninety-nine people out of a hundred would have annoyed Anne bitterly; but the way in which Mr. Douglas said it made her feel that she had received a very real and pleasing compliment. She smiled appreciatively at him and dropped obligingly behind on the moonlit road.
children.prevalue: Such a speech from ninety nine people out of a hundred would have annoyed Anne bitterly but the way in which Mr Douglas said it made her feel that she had received a very real and pleasing compliment She smiled appreciatively at him and dropped obligingly behind on the moonlit road

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: So Janet had a beau! Anne was delighted. Janet would make a paragon of a wife--cheery, economical, tolerant, and a very queen of cooks. It would be a flagrant waste on Nature's part to keep her a permanent old maid.
children.prevalue: So Janet had a beau Anne was delighted Janet would make a paragon of a wife cheery economical tolerant and a very queen of cooks It would be a flagrant waste on Nature s part to keep her a permanent old maid

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: John Douglas asked me to take you up to see his mother, said Janet the next day. She's bed-rid a lot of the time and never goes out of the house. But she's powerful fond of company and always wants to see my boarders. Can you go up this evening?
children.prevalue: John Douglas asked me to take you up to see his mother said Janet the next day She s bed rid a lot of the time and never goes out of the house But she s powerful fond of company and always wants to see my boarders Can you go up this evening

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Anne assented; but later in the day Mr. Douglas called on his mother's behalf to invite them up to tea on Saturday evening.
children.prevalue: Anne assented but later in the day Mr Douglas called on his mother s behalf to invite them up to tea on Saturday evening

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh, why didn't you put on your pretty pansy dress? asked Anne, when they left home. It was a hot day, and poor Janet, between her excitement and her heavy black cashmere dress, looked as if she were being broiled alive.
children.prevalue: Oh why didn t you put on your pretty pansy dress asked Anne when they left home It was a hot day and poor Janet between her excitement and her heavy black cashmere dress looked as if she were being broiled alive

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Old Mrs. Douglas would think it terrible frivolous and unsuitable, I'm afraid. John likes that dress, though, she added wistfully.
children.prevalue: Old Mrs Douglas would think it terrible frivolous and unsuitable I m afraid John likes that dress though she added wistfully

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The old Douglas homestead was half a mile from Wayside cresting a windy hill. The house itself was large and comfortable, old enough to be dignified, and girdled with maple groves and orchards. There were big, trim barns behind it, and everything bespoke prosperity. Whatever the patient endurance in Mr. Douglas' face had meant it hadn't, so Anne reflected, meant debts and duns.
children.prevalue: The old Douglas homestead was half a mile from Wayside cresting a windy hill The house itself was large and comfortable old enough to be dignified and girdled with maple groves and orchards There were big trim barns behind it and everything bespoke prosperity Whatever the patient endurance in Mr Douglas face had meant it hadn t so Anne reflected meant debts and duns

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: John Douglas met them at the door and took them into the sitting-room, where his mother was enthroned in an armchair.
children.prevalue: John Douglas met them at the door and took them into the sitting room where his mother was enthroned in an armchair

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Anne had expected old Mrs. Douglas to be tall and thin, because Mr. Douglas was. Instead, she was a tiny scrap of a woman, with soft pink cheeks, mild blue eyes, and a mouth like a baby's. Dressed in a beautiful, fashionably-made black silk dress, with a fluffy white shawl over her shoulders, and her snowy hair surmounted by a dainty lace cap, she might have posed as a grandmother doll.
children.prevalue: Anne had expected old Mrs Douglas to be tall and thin because Mr Douglas was Instead she was a tiny scrap of a woman with soft pink cheeks mild blue eyes and a mouth like a baby s Dressed in a beautiful fashionably made black silk dress with a fluffy white shawl over her shoulders and her snowy hair surmounted by a dainty lace cap she might have posed as a grandmother doll

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: How do you do, Janet dear? she said sweetly. I am so glad to see you again, dear. She put up her pretty old face to be kissed. And this is our new teacher. I'm delighted to meet you. My son has been singing your praises until I'm half jealous, and I'm sure Janet ought to be wholly so.
children.prevalue: How do you do Janet dear she said sweetly I am so glad to see you again dear She put up her pretty old face to be kissed And this is our new teacher I m delighted to meet you My son has been singing your praises until I m half jealous and I m sure Janet ought to be wholly so

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Poor Janet blushed, Anne said something polite and conventional, and then everybody sat down and made talk. It was hard work, even for Anne, for nobody seemed at ease except old Mrs. Douglas, who certainly did not find any difficulty in talking. She made Janet sit by her and stroked her hand occasionally. Janet sat and smiled, looking horribly uncomfortable in her hideous dress, and John Douglas sat without smiling.
children.prevalue: Poor Janet blushed Anne said something polite and conventional and then everybody sat down and made talk It was hard work even for Anne for nobody seemed at ease except old Mrs Douglas who certainly did not find any difficulty in talking She made Janet sit by her and stroked her hand occasionally Janet sat and smiled looking horribly uncomfortable in her hideous dress and John Douglas sat without smiling

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: At the tea table Mrs. Douglas gracefully asked Janet to pour the tea. Janet turned redder than ever but did it. Anne wrote a description of that meal to Stella.
children.prevalue: At the tea table Mrs Douglas gracefully asked Janet to pour the tea Janet turned redder than ever but did it Anne wrote a description of that meal to Stella

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We had cold tongue and chicken and strawberry preserves, lemon pie and tarts and chocolate cake and raisin cookies and pound cake and fruit cake--and a few other things, including more pie--caramel pie, I think it was. After I had eaten twice as much as was good for me, Mrs. Douglas sighed and said she feared she had nothing to tempt my appetite.
children.prevalue: We had cold tongue and chicken and strawberry preserves lemon pie and tarts and chocolate cake and raisin cookies and pound cake and fruit cake and a few other things including more pie caramel pie I think it was After I had eaten twice as much as was good for me Mrs Douglas sighed and said she feared she had nothing to tempt my appetite

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'I'm afraid dear Janet's cooking has spoiled you for any other,' she said sweetly. 'Of course nobody in Valley Road aspires to rival HER. WON'T you have another piece of pie, Miss Shirley? You haven't eaten ANYTHING.'
children.prevalue: I m afraid dear Janet s cooking has spoiled you for any other she said sweetly Of course nobody in Valley Road aspires to rival HER WON T you have another piece of pie Miss Shirley You haven t eaten ANYTHING

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Stella, I had eaten a helping of tongue and one of chicken, three biscuits, a generous allowance of preserves, a piece of pie, a tart, and a square of chocolate cake!
children.prevalue: Stella I had eaten a helping of tongue and one of chicken three biscuits a generous allowance of preserves a piece of pie a tart and a square of chocolate cake

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: After tea Mrs. Douglas smiled benevolently and told John to take dear Janet out into the garden and get her some roses. Miss Shirley will keep me company while you are out--won't you? she said plaintively. She settled down in her armchair with a sigh.
children.prevalue: After tea Mrs Douglas smiled benevolently and told John to take dear Janet out into the garden and get her some roses Miss Shirley will keep me company while you are out won t you she said plaintively She settled down in her armchair with a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I am a very frail old woman, Miss Shirley. For over twenty years I've been a great sufferer. For twenty long, weary years I've been dying by inches.
children.prevalue: I am a very frail old woman Miss Shirley For over twenty years I ve been a great sufferer For twenty long weary years I ve been dying by inches

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: How painful! said Anne, trying to be sympathetic and succeeding only in feeling idiotic.
children.prevalue: How painful said Anne trying to be sympathetic and succeeding only in feeling idiotic

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: There have been scores of nights when they've thought I could never live to see the dawn, went on Mrs. Douglas solemnly. Nobody knows what I've gone through--nobody can know but myself. Well, it can't last very much longer now. My weary pilgrimage will soon be over, Miss Shirley. It is a great comfort to me that John will have such a good wife to look after him when his mother is gone--a great comfort, Miss Shirley.
children.prevalue: There have been scores of nights when they ve thought I could never live to see the dawn went on Mrs Douglas solemnly Nobody knows what I ve gone through nobody can know but myself Well it can t last very much longer now My weary pilgrimage will soon be over Miss Shirley It is a great comfort to me that John will have such a good wife to look after him when his mother is gone a great comfort Miss Shirley

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Janet is a lovely woman, said Anne warmly.
children.prevalue: Janet is a lovely woman said Anne warmly

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Lovely! A beautiful character, assented Mrs. Douglas. And a perfect housekeeper--something I never was. My health would not permit it, Miss Shirley. I am indeed thankful that John has made such a wise choice. I hope and believe that he will be happy. He is my only son, Miss Shirley, and his happiness lies very near my heart.
children.prevalue: Lovely A beautiful character assented Mrs Douglas And a perfect housekeeper something I never was My health would not permit it Miss Shirley I am indeed thankful that John has made such a wise choice I hope and believe that he will be happy He is my only son Miss Shirley and his happiness lies very near my heart

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Of course, said Anne stupidly. For the first time in her life she was stupid. Yet she could not imagine why. She seemed to have absolutely nothing to say to this sweet, smiling, angelic old lady who was patting her hand so kindly.
children.prevalue: Of course said Anne stupidly For the first time in her life she was stupid Yet she could not imagine why She seemed to have absolutely nothing to say to this sweet smiling angelic old lady who was patting her hand so kindly

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Come and see me soon again, dear Janet, said Mrs. Douglas lovingly, when they left. You don't come half often enough. But then I suppose John will be bringing you here to stay all the time one of these days.  Anne, happening to glance at John Douglas, as his mother spoke, gave a positive start of dismay. He looked as a tortured man might look when his tormentors gave the rack the last turn of possible endurance. She felt sure he must be ill and hurried poor blushing Janet away.
children.prevalue: Come and see me soon again dear Janet said Mrs Douglas lovingly when they left You don t come half often enough But then I suppose John will be bringing you here to stay all the time one of these days Anne happening to glance at John Douglas as his mother spoke gave a positive start of dismay He looked as a tortured man might look when his tormentors gave the rack the last turn of possible endurance She felt sure he must be ill and hurried poor blushing Janet away

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Isn't old Mrs. Douglas a sweet woman? asked Janet, as they went down the road.
children.prevalue: Isn t old Mrs Douglas a sweet woman asked Janet as they went down the road

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: M--m, answered Anne absently. She was wondering why John Douglas had looked so.
children.prevalue: M m answered Anne absently She was wondering why John Douglas had looked so

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: She's been a terrible sufferer, said Janet feelingly. She takes terrible spells. It keeps John all worried up. He's scared to leave home for fear his mother will take a spell and nobody there but the hired girl.
children.prevalue: She s been a terrible sufferer said Janet feelingly She takes terrible spells It keeps John all worried up He s scared to leave home for fear his mother will take a spell and nobody there but the hired girl

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: He Just Kept Coming and Coming
children.prevalue: He Just Kept Coming and Coming

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Three days later Anne came home from school and found Janet crying. Tears and Janet seemed so incongruous that Anne was honestly alarmed.
children.prevalue: Three days later Anne came home from school and found Janet crying Tears and Janet seemed so incongruous that Anne was honestly alarmed

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Oh, what is the matter? she cried anxiously.
children.prevalue: Oh what is the matter she cried anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I'm--I'm forty today, sobbed Janet.
children.prevalue: I m I m forty today sobbed Janet

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Well, you were nearly that yesterday and it didn't hurt, comforted Anne, trying not to smile.
children.prevalue: Well you were nearly that yesterday and it didn t hurt comforted Anne trying not to smile

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But--but, went on Janet with a big gulp, John Douglas won't ask me to marry him.
children.prevalue: But but went on Janet with a big gulp John Douglas won t ask me to marry him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh, but he will, said Anne lamely. You must give him time, Janet
children.prevalue: Oh but he will said Anne lamely You must give him time Janet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Time! said Janet with indescribable scorn. He has had twenty years. How much time does he want?
children.prevalue: Time said Janet with indescribable scorn He has had twenty years How much time does he want

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Do you mean that John Douglas has been coming to see you for twenty years?
children.prevalue: Do you mean that John Douglas has been coming to see you for twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: He has. And he has never so much as mentioned marriage to me. And I don't believe he ever will now. I've never said a word to a mortal about it, but it seems to me I've just got to talk it out with some one at last or go crazy. John Douglas begun to go with me twenty years ago, before mother died. Well, he kept coming and coming, and after a spell I begun making quilts and things; but he never said anything about getting married, only just kept coming and coming. There wasn't anything I could do. Mother died when we'd been going together for eight years. I thought he maybe would speak out then, seeing as I was left alone in the world. He was real kind and feeling, and did everything he could for me, but he never said marry. And that's the way it has been going on ever since. People blame ME for it. They say I won't marry him because his mother is so sickly and I don't want the bother of waiting on her. Why, I'd LOVE to wait on John's mother! But I let them think so. I'd rather they'd blame me than pity me! It's so dreadful humiliating that John won't ask me. And WHY won't he? Seems to me if I only knew his reason I wouldn't mind it so much.
children.prevalue: He has And he has never so much as mentioned marriage to me And I don t believe he ever will now I ve never said a word to a mortal about it but it seems to me I ve just got to talk it out with some one at last or go crazy John Douglas begun to go with me twenty years ago before mother died Well he kept coming and coming and after a spell I begun making quilts and things but he never said anything about getting married only just kept coming and coming There wasn t anything I could do Mother died when we d been going together for eight years I thought he maybe would speak out then seeing as I was left alone in the world He was real kind and feeling and did everything he could for me but he never said marry And that s the way it has been going on ever since People blame ME for it They say I won t marry him because his mother is so sickly and I don t want the bother of waiting on her Why I d LOVE to wait on John s mother But I let them think so I d rather they d blame me than pity me It s so dreadful humiliating that John won t ask me And WHY won t he Seems to me if I only knew his reason I wouldn t mind it so much

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Perhaps his mother doesn't want him to marry anybody, suggested Anne.
children.prevalue: Perhaps his mother doesn t want him to marry anybody suggested Anne

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, she does. She's told me time and again that she'd love to see John settled before her time comes. She's always giving him hints--you heard her yourself the other day. I thought I'd ha' gone through the floor.
children.prevalue: Oh she does She s told me time and again that she d love to see John settled before her time comes She s always giving him hints you heard her yourself the other day I thought I d ha gone through the floor

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It's beyond me, said Anne helplessly. She thought of Ludovic Speed. But the cases were not parallel. John Douglas was not a man of Ludovic's type.
children.prevalue: It s beyond me said Anne helplessly She thought of Ludovic Speed But the cases were not parallel John Douglas was not a man of Ludovic s type

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: You should show more spirit, Janet, she went on resolutely. Why didn't you send him about his business long ago?
children.prevalue: You should show more spirit Janet she went on resolutely Why didn t you send him about his business long ago

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I couldn't, said poor Janet pathetically. You see, Anne, I've always been awful fond of John. He might just as well keep coming as not, for there was never anybody else I'd want, so it didn't matter.
children.prevalue: I couldn t said poor Janet pathetically You see Anne I ve always been awful fond of John He might just as well keep coming as not for there was never anybody else I d want so it didn t matter

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But it might have made him speak out like a man, urged Anne.
children.prevalue: But it might have made him speak out like a man urged Anne

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Janet shook her head.
children.prevalue: Janet shook her head

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No, I guess not. I was afraid to try, anyway, for fear he'd think I meant it and just go. I suppose I'm a poor-spirited creature, but that is how I feel. And I can't help it.
children.prevalue: No I guess not I was afraid to try anyway for fear he d think I meant it and just go I suppose I m a poor spirited creature but that is how I feel And I can t help it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oh, you COULD help it, Janet. It isn't too late yet. Take a firm stand. Let that man know you are not going to endure his shillyshallying any longer. I'LL back you up.
children.prevalue: Oh you COULD help it Janet It isn t too late yet Take a firm stand Let that man know you are not going to endure his shillyshallying any longer I LL back you up

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I dunno, said Janet hopelessly. I dunno if I could ever get up enough spunk. Things have drifted so long. But I'll think it over.
children.prevalue: I dunno said Janet hopelessly I dunno if I could ever get up enough spunk Things have drifted so long But I ll think it over

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Anne felt that she was disappointed in John Douglas. She had liked him so well, and she had not thought him the sort of man who would play fast and loose with a woman's feelings for twenty years. He certainly should be taught a lesson, and Anne felt vindictively that she would enjoy seeing the process. Therefore she was delighted when Janet told her, as they were going to prayer-meeting the next night, that she meant to show some sperrit.
children.prevalue: Anne felt that she was disappointed in John Douglas She had liked him so well and she had not thought him the sort of man who would play fast and loose with a woman s feelings for twenty years He certainly should be taught a lesson and Anne felt vindictively that she would enjoy seeing the process Therefore she was delighted when Janet told her as they were going to prayer meeting the next night that she meant to show some sperrit

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I'll let John Douglas see I'm not going to be trodden on any longer.
children.prevalue: I ll let John Douglas see I m not going to be trodden on any longer

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You are perfectly right, said Anne emphatically.
children.prevalue: You are perfectly right said Anne emphatically

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: When prayer-meeting was over John Douglas came up with his usual request. Janet looked frightened but resolute.
children.prevalue: When prayer meeting was over John Douglas came up with his usual request Janet looked frightened but resolute

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: No, thank you, she said icily. I know the road home pretty well alone. I ought to, seeing I've been traveling it for forty years. So you needn't trouble yourself, MR. Douglas.
children.prevalue: No thank you she said icily I know the road home pretty well alone I ought to seeing I ve been traveling it for forty years So you needn t trouble yourself MR Douglas

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Anne was looking at John Douglas; and, in that brilliant moonlight, she saw the last twist of the rack again. Without a word he turned and strode down the road.
children.prevalue: Anne was looking at John Douglas and in that brilliant moonlight she saw the last twist of the rack again Without a word he turned and strode down the road

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Stop! Stop! Anne called wildly after him, not caring in the least for the other dumbfounded onlookers. Mr. Douglas, stop! Come back.
children.prevalue: Stop Stop Anne called wildly after him not caring in the least for the other dumbfounded onlookers Mr Douglas stop Come back

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: John Douglas stopped but he did not come back. Anne flew down the road, caught his arm and fairly dragged him back to Janet.
children.prevalue: John Douglas stopped but he did not come back Anne flew down the road caught his arm and fairly dragged him back to Janet

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: You must come back, she said imploringly. It's all a mistake, Mr. Douglas--all my fault. I made Janet do it. She didn't want to--but it's all right now, isn't it, Janet?
children.prevalue: You must come back she said imploringly It s all a mistake Mr Douglas all my fault I made Janet do it She didn t want to but it s all right now isn t it Janet

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Without a word Janet took his arm and walked away. Anne followed them meekly home and slipped in by the back door.
children.prevalue: Without a word Janet took his arm and walked away Anne followed them meekly home and slipped in by the back door

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well, you are a nice person to back me up, said Janet sarcastically.
children.prevalue: Well you are a nice person to back me up said Janet sarcastically

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I couldn't help it, Janet, said Anne repentantly. I just felt as if I had stood by and seen murder done. I HAD to run after him.
children.prevalue: I couldn t help it Janet said Anne repentantly I just felt as if I had stood by and seen murder done I HAD to run after him

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oh, I'm just as glad you did. When I saw John Douglas making off down that road I just felt as if every little bit of joy and happiness that was left in my life was going with him. It was an awful feeling.
children.prevalue: Oh I m just as glad you did When I saw John Douglas making off down that road I just felt as if every little bit of joy and happiness that was left in my life was going with him It was an awful feeling

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Did he ask you why you did it? asked Anne.
children.prevalue: Did he ask you why you did it asked Anne

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: No, he never said a word about it, replied Janet dully.
children.prevalue: No he never said a word about it replied Janet dully

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: John Douglas Speaks at Last
children.prevalue: John Douglas Speaks at Last

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Anne was not without a feeble hope that something might come of it after all. But nothing did. John Douglas came and took Janet driving, and walked home from prayer-meeting with her, as he had been doing for twenty years, and as he seemed likely to do for twenty years more. The summer waned. Anne taught her school and wrote letters and studied a little. Her walks to and from school were pleasant. She always went by way of the swamp; it was a lovely place--a boggy soil, green with the greenest of mossy hillocks; a silvery brook meandered through it and spruces stood erectly, their boughs a-trail with gray-green mosses, their roots overgrown with all sorts of woodland lovelinesses.
children.prevalue: Anne was not without a feeble hope that something might come of it after all But nothing did John Douglas came and took Janet driving and walked home from prayer meeting with her as he had been doing for twenty years and as he seemed likely to do for twenty years more The summer waned Anne taught her school and wrote letters and studied a little Her walks to and from school were pleasant She always went by way of the swamp it was a lovely place a boggy soil green with the greenest of mossy hillocks a silvery brook meandered through it and spruces stood erectly their boughs a trail with gray green mosses their roots overgrown with all sorts of woodland lovelinesses

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Nevertheless, Anne found life in Valley Road a little monotonous. To be sure, there was one diverting incident.
children.prevalue: Nevertheless Anne found life in Valley Road a little monotonous To be sure there was one diverting incident

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: She had not seen the lank, tow-headed Samuel of the peppermints since the evening of his call, save for chance meetings on the road. But one warm August night he appeared, and solemnly seated himself on the rustic bench by the porch. He wore his usual working habiliments, consisting of varipatched trousers, a blue jean shirt, out at the elbows, and a ragged straw hat. He was chewing a straw and he kept on chewing it while he looked solemnly at Anne. Anne laid her book aside with a sigh and took up her doily. Conversation with Sam was really out of the question.
children.prevalue: She had not seen the lank tow headed Samuel of the peppermints since the evening of his call save for chance meetings on the road But one warm August night he appeared and solemnly seated himself on the rustic bench by the porch He wore his usual working habiliments consisting of varipatched trousers a blue jean shirt out at the elbows and a ragged straw hat He was chewing a straw and he kept on chewing it while he looked solemnly at Anne Anne laid her book aside with a sigh and took up her doily Conversation with Sam was really out of the question

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: After a long silence Sam suddenly spoke.
children.prevalue: After a long silence Sam suddenly spoke

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I'm leaving over there, he said abruptly, waving his straw in the direction of the neighboring house.
children.prevalue: I m leaving over there he said abruptly waving his straw in the direction of the neighboring house

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh, are you? said Anne politely.
children.prevalue: Oh are you said Anne politely

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yep.
children.prevalue: Yep

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And where are you going now?
children.prevalue: And where are you going now

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Wall, I've been thinking some of gitting a place of my own. There's one that'd suit me over at Millersville. But ef I rents it I'll want a woman.
children.prevalue: Wall I ve been thinking some of gitting a place of my own There s one that d suit me over at Millersville But ef I rents it I ll want a woman

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I suppose so, said Anne vaguely.
children.prevalue: I suppose so said Anne vaguely

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Yep.
children.prevalue: Yep

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: There was another long silence. Finally Sam removed his straw again and said,
children.prevalue: There was another long silence Finally Sam removed his straw again and said

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Will yeh hev me?
children.prevalue: Will yeh hev me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Wh--a--t! gasped Anne.
children.prevalue: Wh a t gasped Anne

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Will yeh hev me?
children.prevalue: Will yeh hev me

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Do you mean--MARRY you? queried poor Anne feebly.
children.prevalue: Do you mean MARRY you queried poor Anne feebly

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yep.
children.prevalue: Yep

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Why, I'm hardly acquainted with you, cried Anne indignantly.
children.prevalue: Why I m hardly acquainted with you cried Anne indignantly

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: But yeh'd git acquainted with me after we was married, said Sam.
children.prevalue: But yeh d git acquainted with me after we was married said Sam

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Anne gathered up her poor dignity.
children.prevalue: Anne gathered up her poor dignity

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Certainly I won't marry you, she said haughtily.
children.prevalue: Certainly I won t marry you she said haughtily

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Wall, yeh might do worse, expostulated Sam. I'm a good worker and I've got some money in the bank.
children.prevalue: Wall yeh might do worse expostulated Sam I m a good worker and I ve got some money in the bank

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Don't speak of this to me again. Whatever put such an idea into your head? said Anne, her sense of humor getting the better of her wrath. It was such an absurd situation.
children.prevalue: Don t speak of this to me again Whatever put such an idea into your head said Anne her sense of humor getting the better of her wrath It was such an absurd situation

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yeh're a likely-looking girl and hev a right-smart way o' stepping,  said Sam. I don't want no lazy woman. Think it over. I won't change my mind yit awhile. Wall, I must be gitting. Gotter milk the cows.
children.prevalue: Yeh re a likely looking girl and hev a right smart way o stepping said Sam I don t want no lazy woman Think it over I won t change my mind yit awhile Wall I must be gitting Gotter milk the cows

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Anne's illusions concerning proposals had suffered so much of late years that there were few of them left. So she could laugh wholeheartedly over this one, not feeling any secret sting. She mimicked poor Sam to Janet that night, and both of them laughed immoderately over his plunge into sentiment.
children.prevalue: Anne s illusions concerning proposals had suffered so much of late years that there were few of them left So she could laugh wholeheartedly over this one not feeling any secret sting She mimicked poor Sam to Janet that night and both of them laughed immoderately over his plunge into sentiment

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: One afternoon, when Anne's sojourn in Valley Road was drawing to a close, Alec Ward came driving down to Wayside in hot haste for Janet.
children.prevalue: One afternoon when Anne s sojourn in Valley Road was drawing to a close Alec Ward came driving down to Wayside in hot haste for Janet

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: They want you at the Douglas place quick, he said. I really believe old Mrs. Douglas is going to die at last, after pretending to do it for twenty years.
children.prevalue: They want you at the Douglas place quick he said I really believe old Mrs Douglas is going to die at last after pretending to do it for twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Janet ran to get her hat. Anne asked if Mrs. Douglas was worse than usual.
children.prevalue: Janet ran to get her hat Anne asked if Mrs Douglas was worse than usual

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: She's not half as bad, said Alec solemnly, and that's what makes me think it's serious. Other times she'd be screaming and throwing herself all over the place. This time she's lying still and mum. When Mrs. Douglas is mum she is pretty sick, you bet.
children.prevalue: She s not half as bad said Alec solemnly and that s what makes me think it s serious Other times she d be screaming and throwing herself all over the place This time she s lying still and mum When Mrs Douglas is mum she is pretty sick you bet

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You don't like old Mrs. Douglas? said Anne curiously.
children.prevalue: You don t like old Mrs Douglas said Anne curiously

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I like cats as IS cats. I don't like cats as is women, was Alec's cryptic reply.
children.prevalue: I like cats as IS cats I don t like cats as is women was Alec s cryptic reply

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Janet came home in the twilight.
children.prevalue: Janet came home in the twilight

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Mrs. Douglas is dead, she said wearily. She died soon after I got there. She just spoke to me once--'I suppose you'll marry John now?' she said. It cut me to the heart, Anne. To think John's own mother thought I wouldn't marry him because of her! I couldn't say a word either--there were other women there. I was thankful John had gone out.
children.prevalue: Mrs Douglas is dead she said wearily She died soon after I got there She just spoke to me once I suppose you ll marry John now she said It cut me to the heart Anne To think John s own mother thought I wouldn t marry him because of her I couldn t say a word either there were other women there I was thankful John had gone out

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Janet began to cry drearily. But Anne brewed her a hot drink of ginger tea to her comforting. To be sure, Anne discovered later on that she had used white pepper instead of ginger; but Janet never knew the difference.
children.prevalue: Janet began to cry drearily But Anne brewed her a hot drink of ginger tea to her comforting To be sure Anne discovered later on that she had used white pepper instead of ginger but Janet never knew the difference

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The evening after the funeral Janet and Anne were sitting on the front porch steps at sunset. The wind had fallen asleep in the pinelands and lurid sheets of heat-lightning flickered across the northern skies. Janet wore her ugly black dress and looked her very worst, her eyes and nose red from crying. They talked little, for Janet seemed faintly to resent Anne's efforts to cheer her up. She plainly preferred to be miserable.
children.prevalue: The evening after the funeral Janet and Anne were sitting on the front porch steps at sunset The wind had fallen asleep in the pinelands and lurid sheets of heat lightning flickered across the northern skies Janet wore her ugly black dress and looked her very worst her eyes and nose red from crying They talked little for Janet seemed faintly to resent Anne s efforts to cheer her up She plainly preferred to be miserable

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Suddenly the gate-latch clicked and John Douglas strode into the garden. He walked towards them straight over the geranium bed. Janet stood up. So did Anne. Anne was a tall girl and wore a white dress; but John Douglas did not see her.
children.prevalue: Suddenly the gate latch clicked and John Douglas strode into the garden He walked towards them straight over the geranium bed Janet stood up So did Anne Anne was a tall girl and wore a white dress but John Douglas did not see her

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Janet, he said, will you marry me?
children.prevalue: Janet he said will you marry me

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The words burst out as if they had been wanting to be said for twenty years and MUST be uttered now, before anything else.
children.prevalue: The words burst out as if they had been wanting to be said for twenty years and MUST be uttered now before anything else

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Janet's face was so red from crying that it couldn't turn any redder, so it turned a most unbecoming purple.
children.prevalue: Janet s face was so red from crying that it couldn t turn any redder so it turned a most unbecoming purple

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Why didn't you ask me before? she said slowly.
children.prevalue: Why didn t you ask me before she said slowly

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I couldn't. She made me promise not to--mother made me promise not to. Nineteen years ago she took a terrible spell. We thought she couldn't live through it. She implored me to promise not to ask you to marry me while she was alive. I didn't want to promise such a thing, even though we all thought she couldn't live very long--the doctor only gave her six months. But she begged it on her knees, sick and suffering. I had to promise.
children.prevalue: I couldn t She made me promise not to mother made me promise not to Nineteen years ago she took a terrible spell We thought she couldn t live through it She implored me to promise not to ask you to marry me while she was alive I didn t want to promise such a thing even though we all thought she couldn t live very long the doctor only gave her six months But she begged it on her knees sick and suffering I had to promise

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What had your mother against me? cried Janet.
children.prevalue: What had your mother against me cried Janet

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Nothing--nothing. She just didn't want another woman--ANY woman--there while she was living. She said if I didn't promise she'd die right there and I'd have killed her. So I promised. And she's held me to that promise ever since, though I've gone on my knees to her in my turn to beg her to let me off.
children.prevalue: Nothing nothing She just didn t want another woman ANY woman there while she was living She said if I didn t promise she d die right there and I d have killed her So I promised And she s held me to that promise ever since though I ve gone on my knees to her in my turn to beg her to let me off

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Why didn't you tell me this? asked Janet chokingly. If I'd only KNOWN! Why didn't you just tell me?
children.prevalue: Why didn t you tell me this asked Janet chokingly If I d only KNOWN Why didn t you just tell me

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: She made me promise I wouldn't tell a soul, said John hoarsely. She swore me to it on the Bible; Janet, I'd never have done it if I'd dreamed it was to be for so long. Janet, you'll never know what I've suffered these nineteen years. I know I've made you suffer, too, but you'll marry me for all, won't you, Janet? Oh, Janet, won't you? I've come as soon as I could to ask you.

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: At this moment the stupefied Anne came to her senses and realized that she had no business to be there. She slipped away and did not see Janet until the next morning, when the latter told her the rest of the story.
children.prevalue: At this moment the stupefied Anne came to her senses and realized that she had no business to be there She slipped away and did not see Janet until the next morning when the latter told her the rest of the story

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: That cruel, relentless, deceitful old woman! cried Anne.
children.prevalue: That cruel relentless deceitful old woman cried Anne

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Hush--she's dead, said Janet solemnly. If she wasn't--but she IS. So we mustn't speak evil of her. But I'm happy at last, Anne. And I wouldn't have minded waiting so long a bit if I'd only known why.
children.prevalue: Hush she s dead said Janet solemnly If she wasn t but she IS So we mustn t speak evil of her But I m happy at last Anne And I wouldn t have minded waiting so long a bit if I d only known why

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: When are you to be married?
children.prevalue: When are you to be married

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Next month. Of course it will be very quiet. I suppose people will talk terrible. They'll say I made enough haste to snap John up as soon as his poor mother was out of the way. John wanted to let them know the truth but I said, 'No, John; after all she was your mother, and we'll keep the secret between us, and not cast any shadow on her memory. I don't mind what people say, now that I know the truth myself. It don't matter a mite. Let it all be buried with the dead' says I to him. So I coaxed him round to agree with me.
children.prevalue: Next month Of course it will be very quiet I suppose people will talk terrible They ll say I made enough haste to snap John up as soon as his poor mother was out of the way John wanted to let them know the truth but I said No John after all she was your mother and we ll keep the secret between us and not cast any shadow on her memory I don t mind what people say now that I know the truth myself It don t matter a mite Let it all be buried with the dead says I to him So I coaxed him round to agree with me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: You're much more forgiving than I could ever be, Anne said, rather crossly.
children.prevalue: You re much more forgiving than I could ever be Anne said rather crossly

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You'll feel differently about a good many things when you get to be my age, said Janet tolerantly. That's one of the things we learn as we grow older--how to forgive. It comes easier at forty than it did at twenty.

children.prevalue: The Last Redmond Year Opens

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Here we are, all back again, nicely sunburned and rejoicing as a strong man to run a race, said Phil, sitting down on a suitcase with a sigh of pleasure. Isn't it jolly to see this dear old Patty's Place again--and Aunty--and the cats? Rusty has lost another piece of ear, hasn't he?
children.prevalue: Here we are all back again nicely sunburned and rejoicing as a strong man to run a race said Phil sitting down on a suitcase with a sigh of pleasure Isn t it jolly to see this dear old Patty s Place again and Aunty and the cats Rusty has lost another piece of ear hasn t he

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Rusty would be the nicest cat in the world if he had no ears at all,  declared Anne loyally from her trunk, while Rusty writhed about her lap in a frenzy of welcome.
children.prevalue: Rusty would be the nicest cat in the world if he had no ears at all declared Anne loyally from her trunk while Rusty writhed about her lap in a frenzy of welcome

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Aren't you glad to see us back, Aunty? demanded Phil.
children.prevalue: Aren t you glad to see us back Aunty demanded Phil

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes. But I wish you'd tidy things up, said Aunt Jamesina plaintively, looking at the wilderness of trunks and suitcases by which the four laughing, chattering girls were surrounded. You can talk just as well later on. Work first and then play used to be my motto when I was a girl.
children.prevalue: Yes But I wish you d tidy things up said Aunt Jamesina plaintively looking at the wilderness of trunks and suitcases by which the four laughing chattering girls were surrounded You can talk just as well later on Work first and then play used to be my motto when I was a girl

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Oh, we've just reversed that in this generation, Aunty. OUR motto is play your play and then dig in. You can do your work so much better if you've had a good bout of play first.
children.prevalue: Oh we ve just reversed that in this generation Aunty OUR motto is play your play and then dig in You can do your work so much better if you ve had a good bout of play first

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: If you are going to marry a minister, said Aunt Jamesina, picking up Joseph and her knitting and resigning herself to the inevitable with the charming grace that made her the queen of housemothers, you will have to give up such expressions as 'dig in.'
children.prevalue: If you are going to marry a minister said Aunt Jamesina picking up Joseph and her knitting and resigning herself to the inevitable with the charming grace that made her the queen of housemothers you will have to give up such expressions as dig in

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why? moaned Phil. Oh, why must a minister's wife be supposed to utter only prunes and prisms? I shan't. Everybody on Patterson Street uses slang--that is to say, metaphorical language--and if I didn't they would think me insufferably proud and stuck up.
children.prevalue: Why moaned Phil Oh why must a minister s wife be supposed to utter only prunes and prisms I shan t Everybody on Patterson Street uses slang that is to say metaphorical language and if I didn t they would think me insufferably proud and stuck up

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Have you broken the news to your family? asked Priscilla, feeding the Sarah-cat bits from her lunchbasket.
children.prevalue: Have you broken the news to your family asked Priscilla feeding the Sarah cat bits from her lunchbasket

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Phil nodded.
children.prevalue: Phil nodded

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: How did they take it?
children.prevalue: How did they take it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, mother rampaged. But I stood rockfirm--even I, Philippa Gordon, who never before could hold fast to anything. Father was calmer. Father's own daddy was a minister, so you see he has a soft spot in his heart for the cloth. I had Jo up to Mount Holly, after mother grew calm, and they both loved him. But mother gave him some frightful hints in every conversation regarding what she had hoped for me. Oh, my vacation pathway hasn't been exactly strewn with roses, girls dear. But--I've won out and I've got Jo. Nothing else matters.
children.prevalue: Oh mother rampaged But I stood rockfirm even I Philippa Gordon who never before could hold fast to anything Father was calmer Father s own daddy was a minister so you see he has a soft spot in his heart for the cloth I had Jo up to Mount Holly after mother grew calm and they both loved him But mother gave him some frightful hints in every conversation regarding what she had hoped for me Oh my vacation pathway hasn t been exactly strewn with roses girls dear But I ve won out and I ve got Jo Nothing else matters

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: To you, said Aunt Jamesina darkly.
children.prevalue: To you said Aunt Jamesina darkly

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Nor to Jo, either, retorted Phil. You keep on pitying him. Why, pray? I think he's to be envied. He's getting brains, beauty, and a heart of gold in ME.
children.prevalue: Nor to Jo either retorted Phil You keep on pitying him Why pray I think he s to be envied He s getting brains beauty and a heart of gold in ME

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It's well we know how to take your speeches, said Aunt Jamesina patiently. I hope you don't talk like that before strangers. What would they think?
children.prevalue: It s well we know how to take your speeches said Aunt Jamesina patiently I hope you don t talk like that before strangers What would they think

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Oh, I don't want to know what they think. I don't want to see myself as others see me. I'm sure it would be horribly uncomfortable most of the time. I don't believe Burns was really sincere in that prayer, either.
children.prevalue: Oh I don t want to know what they think I don t want to see myself as others see me I m sure it would be horribly uncomfortable most of the time I don t believe Burns was really sincere in that prayer either

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Oh, I daresay we all pray for some things that we really don't want, if we were only honest enough to look into our hearts, owned Aunt Jamesina candidly. I've a notion that such prayers don't rise very far. _I_ used to pray that I might be enabled to forgive a certain person, but I know now I really didn't want to forgive her. When I finally got that I DID want to I forgave her without having to pray about it.
children.prevalue: Oh I daresay we all pray for some things that we really don t want if we were only honest enough to look into our hearts owned Aunt Jamesina candidly I ve a notion that such prayers don t rise very far I used to pray that I might be enabled to forgive a certain person but I know now I really didn t want to forgive her When I finally got that I DID want to I forgave her without having to pray about it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I can't picture you as being unforgiving for long, said Stella.
children.prevalue: I can t picture you as being unforgiving for long said Stella

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Oh, I used to be. But holding spite doesn't seem worth while when you get along in years.
children.prevalue: Oh I used to be But holding spite doesn t seem worth while when you get along in years

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: That reminds me, said Anne, and told the tale of John and Janet.
children.prevalue: That reminds me said Anne and told the tale of John and Janet

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: And now tell us about that romantic scene you hinted so darkly at in one of your letters, demanded Phil.
children.prevalue: And now tell us about that romantic scene you hinted so darkly at in one of your letters demanded Phil

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Anne acted out Samuel's proposal with great spirit. The girls shrieked with laughter and Aunt Jamesina smiled.
children.prevalue: Anne acted out Samuel s proposal with great spirit The girls shrieked with laughter and Aunt Jamesina smiled

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: It isn't in good taste to make fun of your beaux, she said severely; but, she added calmly, I always did it myself.
children.prevalue: It isn t in good taste to make fun of your beaux she said severely but she added calmly I always did it myself

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Tell us about your beaux, Aunty, entreated Phil. You must have had any number of them.
children.prevalue: Tell us about your beaux Aunty entreated Phil You must have had any number of them

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: They're not in the past tense, retorted Aunt Jamesina. I've got them yet. There are three old widowers at home who have been casting sheep's eyes at me for some time. You children needn't think you own all the romance in the world.
children.prevalue: They re not in the past tense retorted Aunt Jamesina I ve got them yet There are three old widowers at home who have been casting sheep s eyes at me for some time You children needn t think you own all the romance in the world

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Widowers and sheep's eyes don't sound very romantic, Aunty.
children.prevalue: Widowers and sheep s eyes don t sound very romantic Aunty

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, no; but young folks aren't always romantic either. Some of my beaux certainly weren't. I used to laugh at them scandalous, poor boys. There was Jim Elwood--he was always in a sort of day-dream--never seemed to sense what was going on. He didn't wake up to the fact that I'd said 'no' till a year after I'd said it. When he did get married his wife fell out of the sleigh one night when they were driving home from church and he never missed her. Then there was Dan Winston. He knew too much. He knew everything in this world and most of what is in the next. He could give you an answer to any question, even if you asked him when the Judgment Day was to be. Milton Edwards was real nice and I liked him but I didn't marry him. For one thing, he took a week to get a joke through his head, and for another he never asked me. Horatio Reeve was the most interesting beau I ever had. But when he told a story he dressed it up so that you couldn't see it for frills. I never could decide whether he was lying or just letting his imagination run loose.
children.prevalue: Well no but young folks aren t always romantic either Some of my beaux certainly weren t I used to laugh at them scandalous poor boys There was Jim Elwood he was always in a sort of day dream never seemed to sense what was going on He didn t wake up to the fact that I d said no till a year after I d said it When he did get married his wife fell out of the sleigh one night when they were driving home from church and he never missed her Then there was Dan Winston He knew too much He knew everything in this world and most of what is in the next He could give you an answer to any question even if you asked him when the Judgment Day was to be Milton Edwards was real nice and I liked him but I didn t marry him For one thing he took a week to get a joke through his head and for another he never asked me Horatio Reeve was the most interesting beau I ever had But when he told a story he dressed it up so that you couldn t see it for frills I never could decide whether he was lying or just letting his imagination run loose

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And what about the others, Aunty?
children.prevalue: And what about the others Aunty

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Go away and unpack, said Aunt Jamesina, waving Joseph at them by mistake for a needle. The others were too nice to make fun of. I shall respect their memory. There's a box of flowers in your room, Anne. They came about an hour ago.
children.prevalue: Go away and unpack said Aunt Jamesina waving Joseph at them by mistake for a needle The others were too nice to make fun of I shall respect their memory There s a box of flowers in your room Anne They came about an hour ago

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: After the first week the girls of Patty's Place settled down to a steady grind of study; for this was their last year at Redmond and graduation honors must be fought for persistently. Anne devoted herself to English, Priscilla pored over classics, and Philippa pounded away at Mathematics. Sometimes they grew tired, sometimes they felt discouraged, sometimes nothing seemed worth the struggle for it. In one such mood Stella wandered up to the blue room one rainy November evening. Anne sat on the floor in a little circle of light cast by the lamp beside her, amid a surrounding snow of crumpled manuscript.
children.prevalue: After the first week the girls of Patty s Place settled down to a steady grind of study for this was their last year at Redmond and graduation honors must be fought for persistently Anne devoted herself to English Priscilla pored over classics and Philippa pounded away at Mathematics Sometimes they grew tired sometimes they felt discouraged sometimes nothing seemed worth the struggle for it In one such mood Stella wandered up to the blue room one rainy November evening Anne sat on the floor in a little circle of light cast by the lamp beside her amid a surrounding snow of crumpled manuscript

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What in the world are you doing?
children.prevalue: What in the world are you doing

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Just looking over some old Story Club yarns. I wanted something to cheer AND inebriate. I'd studied until the world seemed azure. So I came up here and dug these out of my trunk. They are so drenched in tears and tragedy that they are excruciatingly funny.
children.prevalue: Just looking over some old Story Club yarns I wanted something to cheer AND inebriate I d studied until the world seemed azure So I came up here and dug these out of my trunk They are so drenched in tears and tragedy that they are excruciatingly funny

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I'm blue and discouraged myself, said Stella, throwing herself on the couch. Nothing seems worthwhile. My very thoughts are old. I've thought them all before. What is the use of living after all, Anne?
children.prevalue: I m blue and discouraged myself said Stella throwing herself on the couch Nothing seems worthwhile My very thoughts are old I ve thought them all before What is the use of living after all Anne

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Honey, it's just brain fag that makes us feel that way, and the weather. A pouring rainy night like this, coming after a hard day's grind, would squelch any one but a Mark Tapley. You know it IS worthwhile to live.
children.prevalue: Honey it s just brain fag that makes us feel that way and the weather A pouring rainy night like this coming after a hard day s grind would squelch any one but a Mark Tapley You know it IS worthwhile to live

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, I suppose so. But I can't prove it to myself just now.
children.prevalue: Oh I suppose so But I can t prove it to myself just now

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Just think of all the great and noble souls who have lived and worked in the world, said Anne dreamily. Isn't it worthwhile to come after them and inherit what they won and taught? Isn't it worthwhile to think we can share their inspiration? And then, all the great souls that will come in the future? Isn't it worthwhile to work a little and prepare the way for them--make just one step in their path easier?
children.prevalue: Just think of all the great and noble souls who have lived and worked in the world said Anne dreamily Isn t it worthwhile to come after them and inherit what they won and taught Isn t it worthwhile to think we can share their inspiration And then all the great souls that will come in the future Isn t it worthwhile to work a little and prepare the way for them make just one step in their path easier

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Oh, my mind agrees with you, Anne. But my soul remains doleful and uninspired. I'm always grubby and dingy on rainy nights.
children.prevalue: Oh my mind agrees with you Anne But my soul remains doleful and uninspired I m always grubby and dingy on rainy nights

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Some nights I like the rain--I like to lie in bed and hear it pattering on the roof and drifting through the pines.
children.prevalue: Some nights I like the rain I like to lie in bed and hear it pattering on the roof and drifting through the pines

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I like it when it stays on the roof, said Stella. It doesn't always. I spent a gruesome night in an old country farmhouse last summer. The roof leaked and the rain came pattering down on my bed. There was no poetry in THAT. I had to get up in the 'mirk midnight' and chivy round to pull the bedstead out of the drip--and it was one of those solid, old-fashioned beds that weigh a ton--more or less. And then that drip-drop, drip-drop kept up all night until my nerves just went to pieces. You've no idea what an eerie noise a great drop of rain falling with a mushy thud on a bare floor makes in the night. It sounds like ghostly footsteps and all that sort of thing. What are you laughing over, Anne?
children.prevalue: I like it when it stays on the roof said Stella It doesn t always I spent a gruesome night in an old country farmhouse last summer The roof leaked and the rain came pattering down on my bed There was no poetry in THAT I had to get up in the mirk midnight and chivy round to pull the bedstead out of the drip and it was one of those solid old fashioned beds that weigh a ton more or less And then that drip drop drip drop kept up all night until my nerves just went to pieces You ve no idea what an eerie noise a great drop of rain falling with a mushy thud on a bare floor makes in the night It sounds like ghostly footsteps and all that sort of thing What are you laughing over Anne

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: These stories. As Phil would say they are killing--in more senses than one, for everybody died in them. What dazzlingly lovely heroines we had--and how we dressed them!
children.prevalue: These stories As Phil would say they are killing in more senses than one for everybody died in them What dazzlingly lovely heroines we had and how we dressed them

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Silks--satins--velvets--jewels--laces--they never wore anything else. Here is one of Jane Andrews' stories depicting her heroine as sleeping in a beautiful white satin nightdress trimmed with seed pearls.
children.prevalue: Silks satins velvets jewels laces they never wore anything else Here is one of Jane Andrews stories depicting her heroine as sleeping in a beautiful white satin nightdress trimmed with seed pearls

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Go on, said Stella. I begin to feel that life is worth living as long as there's a laugh in it.
children.prevalue: Go on said Stella I begin to feel that life is worth living as long as there s a laugh in it

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Here's one I wrote. My heroine is disporting herself at a ball 'glittering from head to foot with large diamonds of the first water.' But what booted beauty or rich attire? 'The paths of glory lead but to the grave.' They must either be murdered or die of a broken heart. There was no escape for them.
children.prevalue: Here s one I wrote My heroine is disporting herself at a ball glittering from head to foot with large diamonds of the first water But what booted beauty or rich attire The paths of glory lead but to the grave They must either be murdered or die of a broken heart There was no escape for them

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Let me read some of your stories.
children.prevalue: Let me read some of your stories

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Well, here's my masterpiece. Note its cheerful title--'My Graves.' I shed quarts of tears while writing it, and the other girls shed gallons while I read it. Jane Andrews' mother scolded her frightfully because she had so many handkerchiefs in the wash that week. It's a harrowing tale of the wanderings of a Methodist minister's wife. I made her a Methodist because it was necessary that she should wander. She buried a child every place she lived in. There were nine of them and their graves were severed far apart, ranging from Newfoundland to Vancouver. I described the children, pictured their several death beds, and detailed their tombstones and epitaphs. I had intended to bury the whole nine but when I had disposed of eight my invention of horrors gave out and I permitted the ninth to live as a hopeless cripple.
children.prevalue: Well here s my masterpiece Note its cheerful title My Graves I shed quarts of tears while writing it and the other girls shed gallons while I read it Jane Andrews mother scolded her frightfully because she had so many handkerchiefs in the wash that week It s a harrowing tale of the wanderings of a Methodist minister s wife I made her a Methodist because it was necessary that she should wander She buried a child every place she lived in There were nine of them and their graves were severed far apart ranging from Newfoundland to Vancouver I described the children pictured their several death beds and detailed their tombstones and epitaphs I had intended to bury the whole nine but when I had disposed of eight my invention of horrors gave out and I permitted the ninth to live as a hopeless cripple

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: While Stella read My Graves, punctuating its tragic paragraphs with chuckles, and Rusty slept the sleep of a just cat who has been out all night curled up on a Jane Andrews tale of a beautiful maiden of fifteen who went to nurse in a leper colony--of course dying of the loathsome disease finally--Anne glanced over the other manuscripts and recalled the old days at Avonlea school when the members of the Story Club, sitting under the spruce trees or down among the ferns by the brook, had written them. What fun they had had! How the sunshine and mirth of those olden summers returned as she read. Not all the glory that was Greece or the grandeur that was Rome could weave such wizardry as those funny, tearful tales of the Story Club. Among the manuscripts Anne found one written on sheets of wrapping paper. A wave of laughter filled her gray eyes as she recalled the time and place of its genesis. It was the sketch she had written the day she fell through the roof of the Cobb duckhouse on the Tory Road.
children.prevalue: While Stella read My Graves punctuating its tragic paragraphs with chuckles and Rusty slept the sleep of a just cat who has been out all night curled up on a Jane Andrews tale of a beautiful maiden of fifteen who went to nurse in a leper colony of course dying of the loathsome disease finally Anne glanced over the other manuscripts and recalled the old days at Avonlea school when the members of the Story Club sitting under the spruce trees or down among the ferns by the brook had written them What fun they had had How the sunshine and mirth of those olden summers returned as she read Not all the glory that was Greece or the grandeur that was Rome could weave such wizardry as those funny tearful tales of the Story Club Among the manuscripts Anne found one written on sheets of wrapping paper A wave of laughter filled her gray eyes as she recalled the time and place of its genesis It was the sketch she had written the day she fell through the roof of the Cobb duckhouse on the Tory Road

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Anne glanced over it, then fell to reading it intently. It was a little dialogue between asters and sweet-peas, wild canaries in the lilac bush, and the guardian spirit of the garden. After she had read it, she sat, staring into space; and when Stella had gone she smoothed out the crumpled manuscript.
children.prevalue: Anne glanced over it then fell to reading it intently It was a little dialogue between asters and sweet peas wild canaries in the lilac bush and the guardian spirit of the garden After she had read it she sat staring into space and when Stella had gone she smoothed out the crumpled manuscript

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I believe I will, she said resolutely.
children.prevalue: I believe I will she said resolutely

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The Gardners'Call
children.prevalue: The Gardners Call

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Here is a letter with an Indian stamp for you, Aunt Jimsie, said Phil. Here are three for Stella, and two for Pris, and a glorious fat one for me from Jo. There's nothing for you, Anne, except a circular.
children.prevalue: Here is a letter with an Indian stamp for you Aunt Jimsie said Phil Here are three for Stella and two for Pris and a glorious fat one for me from Jo There s nothing for you Anne except a circular

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Nobody noticed Anne's flush as she took the thin letter Phil tossed her carelessly. But a few minutes later Phil looked up to see a transfigured Anne.
children.prevalue: Nobody noticed Anne s flush as she took the thin letter Phil tossed her carelessly But a few minutes later Phil looked up to see a transfigured Anne

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Honey, what good thing has happened?
children.prevalue: Honey what good thing has happened

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The Youth's Friend has accepted a little sketch I sent them a fortnight ago, said Anne, trying hard to speak as if she were accustomed to having sketches accepted every mail, but not quite succeeding.
children.prevalue: The Youth s Friend has accepted a little sketch I sent them a fortnight ago said Anne trying hard to speak as if she were accustomed to having sketches accepted every mail but not quite succeeding

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Anne Shirley! How glorious! What was it? When is it to be published? Did they pay you for it?
children.prevalue: Anne Shirley How glorious What was it When is it to be published Did they pay you for it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes; they've sent a check for ten dollars, and the editor writes that he would like to see more of my work. Dear man, he shall. It was an old sketch I found in my box. I re-wrote it and sent it in--but I never really thought it could be accepted because it had no plot, said Anne, recalling the bitter experience of Averil's Atonement.
children.prevalue: Yes they ve sent a check for ten dollars and the editor writes that he would like to see more of my work Dear man he shall It was an old sketch I found in my box I re wrote it and sent it in but I never really thought it could be accepted because it had no plot said Anne recalling the bitter experience of Averil s Atonement

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What are you going to do with that ten dollars, Anne? Let's all go up town and get drunk, suggested Phil.
children.prevalue: What are you going to do with that ten dollars Anne Let s all go up town and get drunk suggested Phil

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I AM going to squander it in a wild soulless revel of some sort,  declared Anne gaily. At all events it isn't tainted money--like the check I got for that horrible Reliable Baking Powder story. I spent IT usefully for clothes and hated them every time I put them on.
children.prevalue: I AM going to squander it in a wild soulless revel of some sort declared Anne gaily At all events it isn t tainted money like the check I got for that horrible Reliable Baking Powder story I spent IT usefully for clothes and hated them every time I put them on

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Think of having a real live author at Patty's Place, said Priscilla.
children.prevalue: Think of having a real live author at Patty s Place said Priscilla

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It's a great responsibility, said Aunt Jamesina solemnly.
children.prevalue: It s a great responsibility said Aunt Jamesina solemnly

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Indeed it is, agreed Pris with equal solemnity. Authors are kittle cattle. You never know when or how they will break out. Anne may make copy of us.
children.prevalue: Indeed it is agreed Pris with equal solemnity Authors are kittle cattle You never know when or how they will break out Anne may make copy of us

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I meant that the ability to write for the Press was a great responsibility, said Aunt Jamesina severely, and I hope Anne realizes, it. My daughter used to write stories before she went to the foreign field, but now she has turned her attention to higher things. She used to say her motto was 'Never write a line you would be ashamed to read at your own funeral.' You'd better take that for yours, Anne, if you are going to embark in literature. Though, to be sure, added Aunt Jamesina perplexedly, Elizabeth always used to laugh when she said it. She always laughed so much that I don't know how she ever came to decide on being a missionary. I'm thankful she did--I prayed that she might--but--I wish she hadn't.
children.prevalue: I meant that the ability to write for the Press was a great responsibility said Aunt Jamesina severely and I hope Anne realizes it My daughter used to write stories before she went to the foreign field but now she has turned her attention to higher things She used to say her motto was Never write a line you would be ashamed to read at your own funeral You d better take that for yours Anne if you are going to embark in literature Though to be sure added Aunt Jamesina perplexedly Elizabeth always used to laugh when she said it She always laughed so much that I don t know how she ever came to decide on being a missionary I m thankful she did I prayed that she might but I wish she hadn t

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Then Aunt Jamesina wondered why those giddy girls all laughed.
children.prevalue: Then Aunt Jamesina wondered why those giddy girls all laughed

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Anne's eyes shone all that day; literary ambitions sprouted and budded in her brain; their exhilaration accompanied her to Jennie Cooper's walking party, and not even the sight of Gilbert and Christine, walking just ahead of her and Roy, could quite subdue the sparkle of her starry hopes. Nevertheless, she was not so rapt from things of earth as to be unable to notice that Christine's walk was decidedly ungraceful.
children.prevalue: Anne s eyes shone all that day literary ambitions sprouted and budded in her brain their exhilaration accompanied her to Jennie Cooper s walking party and not even the sight of Gilbert and Christine walking just ahead of her and Roy could quite subdue the sparkle of her starry hopes Nevertheless she was not so rapt from things of earth as to be unable to notice that Christine s walk was decidedly ungraceful

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But I suppose Gilbert looks only at her face. So like a man, thought Anne scornfully.
children.prevalue: But I suppose Gilbert looks only at her face So like a man thought Anne scornfully

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Shall you be home Saturday afternoon? asked Roy.
children.prevalue: Shall you be home Saturday afternoon asked Roy

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: My mother and sisters are coming to call on you, said Roy quietly.
children.prevalue: My mother and sisters are coming to call on you said Roy quietly

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Something went over Anne which might be described as a thrill, but it was hardly a pleasant one. She had never met any of Roy's family; she realized the significance of his statement; and it had, somehow, an irrevocableness about it that chilled her.
children.prevalue: Something went over Anne which might be described as a thrill but it was hardly a pleasant one She had never met any of Roy s family she realized the significance of his statement and it had somehow an irrevocableness about it that chilled her

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I shall be glad to see them, she said flatly; and then wondered if she really would be glad. She ought to be, of course. But would it not be something of an ordeal? Gossip had filtered to Anne regarding the light in which the Gardners viewed the infatuation of son and brother. Roy must have brought pressure to bear in the matter of this call. Anne knew she would be weighed in the balance. From the fact that they had consented to call she understood that, willingly or unwillingly, they regarded her as a possible member of their clan.
children.prevalue: I shall be glad to see them she said flatly and then wondered if she really would be glad She ought to be of course But would it not be something of an ordeal Gossip had filtered to Anne regarding the light in which the Gardners viewed the infatuation of son and brother Roy must have brought pressure to bear in the matter of this call Anne knew she would be weighed in the balance From the fact that they had consented to call she understood that willingly or unwillingly they regarded her as a possible member of their clan

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I shall just be myself. I shall not TRY to make a good impression,  thought Anne loftily. But she was wondering what dress she would better wear Saturday afternoon, and if the new style of high hair-dressing would suit her better than the old; and the walking party was rather spoiled for her. By night she had decided that she would wear her brown chiffon on Saturday, but would do her hair low.
